description.text: For a clearly great solution to printing crack-prone Things with ABS, just wrap a round of plastic film from the kitchen. Can be made almost invisible; you might forget it's there and bang your nose into it while checking out your build.

title: Customizable Jack O' Lantern with Removable Lid

description.text:
The perfect Halloween Jack O'Lantern decoration: an even better (and infinitely healthier) trick-or-treating handout than full-size candy bars! Lid comes off - perfect for placing a small light, candy, or toys inside! Use Customizer to make it your own! There are options to:
-include supports so your creation is printable
-generate only the lid of the pumpkin
-generate only the body of the pumpkin
-create a pumpkin with or without a jack o'lantern face
-change the size

Use customizer to change size, parts rendered, and render quality. Two of the "Parts to Render" options:
-printable_pumpkin_lid
-printable_pumpkin_body_no_face
are printable as they are. The option:
-printable_pumpkin_body_with_face_and_supports
is printable for relatively small sizes, but as the size is increased, more supports may need to be added to make the top row of teeth printable. The other two options:
-pumpkin_body_with_face_and_lid
-pumpkin_body_with_face
are not intended to be printed and are not printable without being modified . The lid can be glued onto the top of the pumpkin body if desired. Leaving the lid separate from the body allows this decoration to also function as a container.

title: Step by step boxed screw manager

description.text:
I quickly designed this box, not printed yet, but sure will be useful for sorting the screws while disassembling a complex device with many sort of screws and many steps.
Just put the first screws in the box #1, then at the second step put the next screws in the 2nd one, and so on.
step back from box 16 to 1 when reassembling your device.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm is enough

Infill:

I used rectilinear 15% , but mainly to have a flat regular bottom.

Notes: the one i printed (see the photo) was sliced by repetier host / slic3r with a size factor of
(X,Y,Y)=>(80%,80%,100%). This was enough for my screws, and easier to fit on a 20x20cm printing bed. as it becomes a 16x16cm box. Anyway, size it the way you want (or can).
I used Sketchup, and provided the skp file if you want to modify the model.

author: megahertz77

description.text:
My uncle originally created one of these out of wood for my Grandma. I decided to redefine the concept and make it more usable for elderly.
Currently at my Grandmas assisted living they play cards for money. As old as they are sometimes its hard to keep track of their coins so I created a coin holder in the front of the Card holder. The coin holder can hold coins of any size.
On the side I included a drink holder. This helps keep drinks from spilling and notifies the elderly whose drink is whose.
The slots for the cards are on a slight angle allowing it to be easier for the cards to be seen. The board itself is on a slight angle keep the cards towards the back a little higher making them easier to see.

title: Lulzbot TAZ Laser-cut Flex Plate (for Dual Extruder)

description.text: Hello! This is a laser-cut option for the flex plate required for dual extrusion on TAZ machines. I was getting really bad warping from the original flex plate from Lulzbot(see image). I have a heated chamber and I think this accelerated the warping of the plate. That being said, it wasn't even a week before the plate started warping. Printing in PC or PC-ABS may prove successful but could get pricey. I want this to be accessible to people without the ability for exotic materials; without leaving the reprap world, so I turned to laser-cutting! Breaking down the original flex-plate into three different shapes, I cut them out on the laser and then sandwiched them together to get the correct thicknesses. The 3mm piece is not necessary and is not seen in photos

comments.text: Nice idea. I did print this and the dual mount out of PC and it works. But of course it is quite difficult to print in PC and took me several attempts to get it to work. And of course the budaschnozzle can't handle PC you'd have to buy the newer hex head.

Hi Roman,
thank you for the compliments, and beautiful your idea!
I only did this because I go fishing for trout in the rivers, and works well. (The only difference I made was to change infill, and when printing is to put small weights inside the square infill, and then end the print so that it remained inside the fish).
When I was looking on the internet I found only models with screws screwed in the PLA, but could not find minnow as "normal", so I decided to make one with wire inside (I think it's the first). And as I wrote in the description: "not wait That others take example from this model to see what other great models will be born!". And so it was! The date of publication are already born 3-4 models with different valid characteristics, and I think that within one year many more will share new models for different types of fishing.

description.text:
I designed this simple hanger so I could keep my brass cleaning brush inside my printer. Now it won't get misplaced! I'm not sure if all these brass brushes have the same sized slots in them, so keep that in mind. If your brush has a similar slot to the one mine has then it should work fine. 
I used some double-sided mounting tape to put it up in the corner of my printer.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100-300 microns

Infill:

15%+

Notes: I printed mine at .2mm layer height and 20% infill with PLA.

Use the redundant shaft from the makibox which is not used at all. Shorten it as much as you can but leave 20 mm extra just incase. Use a 4mm Linear Bearing to get the table to slide nicely. Finally you need to be patient in setting up the square rod because if it is not perfectly aligned, it will not work so you need to unscrew the 2 screws holing the square rod, and adjust until it can go up and down without stopping.
Don't forget a drop of lubricating oil goes a long way.

comments.author: Premium

description.text: A WWII model bomb for model airplanes.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: Be sure to scale it as you need. This model is about a foot long overall as I created it for giant scale airplanes.

I used AutoCad to do the basic drawing as a revolve profile, then imported the drawing into 3D Design and created it as an STL file. It looks pretty good even though I did not use any photos or drawings to copy or trace the profile. The fins are a simple extrusion, thin enough to look okay, but I added a little bit of extra thickness to make it print better. This design  is purely from inside my head based on my memory of old WWII era films and photos.. It just seems to be about the right proportions. You will have to scale it to fit your printer and your particular model size, though. I am also including the build files so you can add hooks or mounting brackets or modify it as you please.

print_settings.Infill:: The model has internal overhang. Read below.

description.text: When looking for something slightly more interesting to store my 3D-printer tools in, I decided to make this creation. It has two semi-large and three smaller compartments, and is well suited for holding utility knives, pens, umbraco keys etc..

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

The model has internal overhang. Read below.

Notes: I sliced this print with the Slic3r setting "Infill only where needed, using a 20% infill and a concentric pattern. Otherwise, the model was given a shell of 4 perimeters (the number of layers on the outer walls, top and bottom). The infill setting used was chosen in order to give support for the internal overhang in the model, while reducing the print time by only printing a thick shell for the areas without internal overhang. If you are not using Sli3r, I would recommend using an denser infill for the first 10mm, and then set the infill to 0%, to reduce print time.

I like the 3/4 PVC pipe for a spool holder, but i want to get this down a bit, so i remixed this one to have some mounting holes, and i will mount 2 of these to some plywood so that i can have a shorter filament holder. 
Edit: I ended up using a extra shelf i got from Ikea's spare parts bin for $1.
I used tinkercad to take out what i wasn't using and added the triangles with holes.

title: Basic Case for Sony Xperia Z1 Compact

description.text:
UPDATE to V4:
  • Hole for wrist strap created to match the one on the phone (bottom right corner).
  • Camera shutter button is more accessible
  • The frame protects slightly the phone when laying flat upside down, but it does not protrudes much, so careful there.
    • UPDATE to V3: V2 has been deleted, and the newest V3 is already fixed. The problems described below should no longer apply. I haven't printed this new version but I will as soon as I get new Filament. The case is improved and some areas too. (FIXED) UPDATE: OK so I tested this design (File Version #2) and I have a couple of improvements to Do.
  • Is that the secondary microphone is covered by the case (I made a measurement mistake of 1mm)
  • The front of the phone is not protected, the frame sits flushed with the device and this is not so good.
    • So I will update soon with the corrections and I will print a new Black case for my dad and probably a purple one for my wife since she wants to buy that phone as well. ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION
    My dad recently bought a Sony Xperia Z1 Compact because it is still a great phone on a decent price... sadly the lack of popularity makes it impossible to find a case in my country... and also there is Zero cases in this community as well.. So I decided to make him one from scratch... This is the second version I designed and the only one I publish... However I will test and update accordingly. So far the only weak spots are the top left corner (due to the headphone jack / and microUSB port flanking it)... and the thin bridge over the Camera Shutter Button. PS: I wish my printer supported ABS so I could test with it...
You might need to clean up a lot of residues between spaces of the frame.

author: Orangewood

description.text:
This 3D-printable device is for the Assistive Technology Challenge. When I read about that challenge, I thought that I need to take part in that challenge and design something that is useful for several people. For a lot of people with disabilities or elderly people it is difficult to do „easy“ things like getting dressed, without the help of others. Many people don’t even think how hard it can be to get on your socks, if you can’t get down to your feet. I first recognized that, when I visited my grandma. She can still do it herself, but it is very difficult, especially as she is ill right now and doesn’t feel that well. But on the other hand she also doesn’t want help (it is also a part of freedom, if you can get dressed yourself and also when you want) I designed the Sockinator to help people to put on their socks or stockings themselves or for their day keepers to make it easier. Right now I have only one size, but I planned to make more versions, so it fits for everyone. If you have additional suggestions on how I could improve the Sockinator, feel free to send them to me. You can adjust the angle of the rod and use the device in two ways.
  • You have the rod on the right side: You put the sock inside the round part and pull the inside around the walls, so the sock is wide open and you can put your foot through it.
  • You have the rod on the left side: You just put the sock around the part. Like that the device just opens the sock.
    • You can try both ways and see what works best for you… To assemble the device you need: 1x M4 hex head screw min 20mm
    1x M4 hex nut
    1x part 1
    1x part 2
    4x part 3
    1x part 4

The idea came from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:65997 which was too small for the PrintrBot Plus 12mm z rods. If your printer settings are out of wack you may have to (SLOWLY) drill out the rod holes. I find a rotozip works best at slow speeds. Take your time and it'll come out well. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/2xI2G0z2rQb Updated STL to the new version that uses less plastic. I

Print two, clean, and put on your Z rods.  The slot on top is big enough for a 12 mm rod or dowel.  This dowl needs to be sturdy enough to support your filement.  You may want to put some clamps on your rod to keep it from sliding out.  I find that binder clips (like used to hold the glass on the  bed) work great.  
You may need to drill out the holes depending on printer settings/alignment.  I use a roto zip (actually a dremel with a rotozip attachment) without the guide.  This cracks the plastic less, and if you use a low speed, it's very easy to get a pro looking job.

description.text: Inspired by "Amplifier" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1016045), I took one of my Tube Whistle designs (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1025843), and incorporated a telescoping amplifier cone; this is the result. A couple of the pictures are of a first revision (that failed to print successfully), and only has two telescoping rings. The first published .stl file, save_19_4_rings.stl has four telescoping rings to extend the amplifying cone. At the moment, my printer is not working (thermistor on extruder went bad), so I'm publishing this without having printed one yet. Hopefully, I'll have one printed before the #MakeItLoud challenge concludes.

Update 11/14/2015:
Printer is working again; I uploaded a new version, save_25.stl that has a flared outer ring, slightly enlarged whistle slots, and a one-layer (.3mm thick) "anchor layer" that needs to be cut away after printing. The dB reading on this whistle was 117.6. Note that the first extension ring is not round on the top; it's slightly off-round to match the whistle body's cone, so it should be rotated to match the profile of the whistle body when extended. All the other rings are circular. https://youtu.be/yd9cgFEKPHQ

Removing the "raft"/"brim" from the finished print. In order to anchor the print sufficiently to the print bed, the object includes a first layer (.30mm in the object; using .25mm print layers, it's one layer) connecting the outer two rings, and the inner three. Using a knife, it should be easy to first just cut through the .25mm layer. Once that's done I removed the material by "scraping" with a sharp knife. The inner-most ring is the trickiest one because the other rings are in the way a bit. Once that ring is cleaned up, you can extend each of the other rings one at a time, and clean up it's bottom edge. Bottom, as printed. Anchor layer cut through; all rings separated Cleaned up; all excess material scraped away.

Post-process We used wall spackle to finish this prop, but you can also use XTC-3D or Bondo in the same fashion if you wish. We used wall spackle because it's cheap, cures fast, and is very lightweight. Steps:
  • Remove support
  • Cover print in filling material of choice (wall spackle, XTC-3D, Bondo, etc)
  • Sand down so that the part is as smooth as possible. It won't be perfect at this point, but that's ok. I use 150 grit sandpaper for this portion.
  • Spray entire part with Filler Primer. I use Rustoleum Filler Primer.
  • Sand entire piece with 150 or 220 grit sandpaper.
  • Sand with Filler Primer and sand again, this time with a finer sandpaper. Repeat this step until the part is as smooth as desired.
  • Paint!

description.text:
WORK IN PROGRESS
10/26/15
So right now it has a couple issues. The main issue is the bits that touch the PS button. They get VERY close. It is pretty much unplayable with just 1, however with 2 once you get the game going it doesnt seem to get in the way.

Using 2, this clip will fit over the PS4 controller and allow use of touchpad and usb port.
It will hold the newest version of the Nexus 7 tablet. With a usb plugged in you can play any game through the PS4 Remote Play App in case you really need to get some RPG action while roomies/family/friends need to get some TV on. Future work
I want to turn it into a single piece that has a hole built in for the PS button and the USB port. I think it will be even more stable as a solid chunk!
I also need to extend the bottom clip up just a tad to kep it from accidentally hitting the PS button

This is a CoreXY large scale printer design that focuses on three things:
  • Maximum print area with given physical dimensions (no space wasted)
  • It is cheap to build one (< 300$)
  • All parts can be printed on small (14cm x 14cm) and dimensionally-inaccurate (= crappy) printer
    • I am tired of seeing printer designs that use 500 mm extrusion\rods and only have like 200 mm2 print area. I am getting upset when I see a part so bulky that it would take 5 hours to print. And you need like 8. That's why I designed Printi4. Underbed dimension: 400 mm x 380 mm
    Effective printing area: x = 280 mm, y = 290 mm, z = 260 mm
    Physical dimensions: x = 490 mm, y = 495 mm, z = 445 mm
    Extrusion length: 400 mm
    Smooth rod lengths: x & y: 400 mm, z: 420 mm Another minor design goal was to change metric fasteners to imperial wherever possible. In Canada we have 150% anti-dumping tax to all metric bolts. In my small town FOUR M4 screws costs $2 and A HUNDRED 8-32 screws (~4.1 mm) costs $3.50. As a bonus – metric people can still use their awesome metric fasteners without changing anything in the design. I really envy you, metric people :-/ Other thing I've emphasised in this design is upgradeability: normally when you think about adding something to an existing design you'd have to replace parts throwing old ones away. This effectively makes you pay twice for the same stuff! That's not the case with Printi4. Only parts you'd have to replace are printed parts (super cheap). You can initially bould your Printi4 with caltilevered bed, thin threaded rods and printed Z stage support; then you can gradually upgrade it by just printing out parts on this same machine! Also, to make your initial build more accessible, most of the parts designed in a fashion that would tolerate inaccuracy in prints – means you can print initial set of parts for Printi4 even on a DVD-drive printer and it would work. By default, Printi4 has a cantilevered bed design that is really not recommended for extensive use. However, it is only there to comply with #3 design focus (printable on small printer). This will allow you to print the non-cantilevered printed parts on your Printi4. All other parts are compatible with both cantilevered and non-cantilevered beds. This printer is physically built and tested with every design iteration. Latest changes to the design can be seen and downloaded from OnShape project. This is why photo of actual thing is a bit different from provided parts. Printi4 uses NEMA 17 motors, 10-24 threaded rods, 8mm smooth rods, E3D v6 (clone/original) hotend, GT2 belt. Electronics:
  • 400W ATX Power Supply
  • RAMPS 1.4 with A4988 drivers (can be adapted to any electronics)
  • Orange Pi as Octoprint Server (Raspberry Pi fits)
  • Webcam

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

50%

Notes: Everything prints well with PLA. ABS should give even better results I guess. Print with as much infill as possible to get rigid parts. You won't need support anywhere except:
  • XY Coupler: nut holes
  • X Carriage and X Dremmel Carriage
  • Dremmel Mounting Halfrings

Oct 28, 2015 Today my flex shaft for Dremmel came in the mail. I will try to adapt it to the X carriage! As such, we need a quick-fit system of some sort. For now I am going to stick with quick release of X axis smooth rods to change the whole X Carriage: this would allow me to develop several toolheads independently not wasting any space on X Carriage to implement quick-fit mechanism on it.
  • Added Quick Release XY Coupling Bottom to parts.
  • Updated XY Coupling Top to accommodate the QR version of bottom.
    You only need one – other one can be fixed (non-QR). So, to have full set of two XY Couplings you'll need two tops and one of each bottom (QR + non-QR).
  • Added Dremmel Flex Shaft X Carriage, attachment ring (use zip ties) and a vac adapter
    I've got my flex shaft in China.
  • Added ATX PSU mounting brackets.

Currently there isn't a dedicated BOM because thing is pretty much in progress. Here are some things that you are definitely going to need:
– Aluminum extrusion 400mm, x12
– Smooth rods, 8mm x 400mm, x4
– Smooth rods, 8mm x 415mm x4 (x2 for cantilevered bed version)
– SK8 Shaft support (search SK8 on aliexpress), x8
– SHF8 Shaft support (search SHF8 on aliexpress), x4
– LM8UU bearings, x12
– 624zz bearings, x8
– Nema 17 motors, x5
– Arduino, Ramps, stepper drivers (use whatever electronics, RAMPS is just the cheapest option)
– ATX Power Supply
– Thrust Ball Bearings, 5mm x 12mm x 4mm, x2
– 10-24 threaded rods, ~380mm, x2
– A box of 8-32 1/4 screws and a box of nuts for them.
For top 3-way corners print out x4 of these, for lower frame angles print x8 of these.

comments.author: toxuin

comments.text:
– I bought extrusion profile from Misumi. Yes, it's 20x20. I don't know what's Type B 6mm :-D It's just usual alu extrusion with M5 hole... Misumi part number HFSB5-2020-400, there are drawings on their website.
– Shaft supports – I guess you can try to print them! I just had some around.
– Thrust bearings are for leadscrew. Since motors are upside down and we are using flexible coupling which is essentially a spring – we need rods to rest upon something or the whole Z axis will have some preload and possibly play. You can skip the bearings if you're not going to use flexible coupling for your leadscrew.
– English is not my native tongue and I have no clue what's hammer nuts. Some kind of T-slot fancy nuts?.. I figured that 8-32 nuts from homedepot (~CA$ 3.50 / 100pc pack) fit misumi extrusion perfectly. You don't need to print any holder (you have to if you're using 6-32 nuts). But if you're from an awesome metric country – I don't know. Probably just better to stick with fancy T-slot nuts. Try M4 nuts – they're closest to 8-32.
– Covering the printer is in my plans as well. First I need to figure something out with heated bed (for this area it's kinda expensive). I will probably cover it with sheet metal since we have plenty of it at local makerspace.
As for covering Z motors – they're more off horizontally than vertically. Here's a picture and here's another one.
If you ever need to PM me i'm toxuin on reprap forum. Would be glad to help!

comments.text: For the type of profile:
comments.author: toxuin

comments.text:
Z motors are upside down because of several reasons. First, one of the design principles involved is "waste no space". Placing motors at the bottom would waste a Z space equal to motor+coupling height. Second, I wanted the printer stand flat (or on tiny rubber feet) and combined with the first point it strikes out the motor placing where they are below the lower frame.
Thrust bearings are cheap ($3 shipped from ali) and the right way to go when you're using flexible coupling.
But since you told me you're going to extend the vertical extrusions I think you can just flip the given Z motor mount and screw it at bottom. This extension should be quite substantial though (height of motor - 20 mm).
In any case, I do not recommend using flexible coupling without thrust bearings. In my design there are only two bearings at bottom and that's a no-no in grown-up CNC world. Normally thrust bearings should be at both ends of a lead screw and in my design I just place the bottom ones and pray to gravity :-D
I'm living in Canada, but was born in Russia. I don't speak french at all. :-)

A parametric test tube rack designed to hold 9 test tubes but configurable to hold any number you can fit in a rectangle. This prints well in PLA but the result may have trouble in the autoclave where temperatures can reach 130C. I printed several in Polymakr PolyFlex (like NinjaFlex but stronger, I think). PolyFlex can handle reheating to about 200C without any trouble so it's fine for the autoclave. Note: Be careful about the material you use to print this, especially if you deal with caustic chemicals or biological specimens in your lab.

We had test tube racks in our lab but they were a little too tall for the centrifuge tubes, they broke too easily and they were getting expensive.  I designed this test tube rack using the dimensions of an existing $15 model.  I experimented with many different methods of building upwards without making it impossible or expensive to print.  The result is what you see here.
You can turn off the bridges if you want by setting "connectors=0" in the .scad file.  It should work as well in most materials, but having the connectors makes the model stronger and able to take more abuse.

Starting from scratch, I drew a basic profile of the America Cup Trophy in Acad2007, taking as a base different images from the cup. I used mostly polylines, and splines. Once I had all the line connected by nodes, I took the profile, and created a part in Inventor. Then on Inventor I selected to create a sketch and just did: Ctrl+C on Acad2007, Ctrl+V on Inventor's sketch, this way I pasted the profile and kept the splines. I revolved the profile in Inventor, and ready!

remixed_from.title: Power Supply Panel for 300W ATX PSU

title: Power Supply Panel for ATX PSU with spring loaded connectors

description.text:
Thanks to modelatolyesi for making his power supply cover in openSCAD. I was quickly able to replace some of the wire connectors he/she used, and added my own hole for some speaker spring loaded terminals that I was using. This file is pretty simple, and easy to change, despite (or maybe because of) the many magic numbers in the code. 
This power supply cover is stretched a little from the original. My PSU is 2mm larger, and I was worried it wouldn't fit. If you want to change the height of the original, take a look at my openscad file.
This has the same spot for the hobby king ampmeter, which I'm pretty sure I own, but I can't find right now. I also liked the video that agentbauman made. His cover would have been remade, but I didn't want to use sketchup. His idea of using the ps_good like for the LED is definitely a good one, so I added a spot for a 5mm LED, and the letters "GOOD" above it. The four wires sticking out the front are for the original molex connectors, which I will solder on when I first need them. I use them to power fans on my soldering station. I get the fans from almost any desktop computer that people give me to dispose of.
I'm happy with this, but if I were to make it again, I would make the height significantly larger. There's 18cm behind the panel, in front of the PSU. That's just not very much when these PSU wires are so stiff and large. I would probably be happy with about 40cm (or 38cm). I'll load the larger one, although I didn't print it, so beware.

description.text: I couldn't find the moulding to match my 20+ year old kitchen cabinets, and I only need a few sections and some corners, so I made my own! I used a contour gauge to measure the depth and drew it out on paper, then made many iterations in scad, printing 2mm tall cross-sections over and over again to compare to my real wooden moulding until I arrived at this final design.

The straight sections print vertically, and are about 100mm tall. The length parameter at the top of the scad controls how tall each section is. Try printing the single straight piece. If that works out, print more singles or 4 at a time with the quad. Then print your corners.  
After printing, coat everything with spray on plastic-primer. I got a can from home depot and it's more than enough to do the whole batch and then some.  
Once primed, you can paint them whatever color you need. If your final color is light, use a light color filament or you'll end up having to use several coats of paint.

This is a parametric design of a bearing house with pockets for hex nuts. The design is based off of a non-parametric design of a bearing housing of Instructable user liquidhandwash that is a component of his 3D printed CNC mill. The overall shape of the housing is a box determined by the parameters Width and Height. The cylindrical recess at the center of the box keeps the bearing in place and is determined by parameters Bearing Outer Diameter and Bearing Height. The difference between Height and Bearing Height determines the thickness of a "flange" at the bottom of the recess. Additionally, the flange has a cylindrical opening determined by the Flange Inner Diameter parameter. The housing is intended to be fastened by means of four bolts and pocketed hex nuts. The dimension of the bolts is determined by Bolt Diameter. The center of a bolt is offset from the edge, according to the Bolt Center Distance From Edge parameter. The hex nut pocket dimension is controlled by Nut Height and Nut Diameter. Keep in mind that, depending on what kind of filament is used for 3D printing, shrinking will be an issue. The bearing and hex nuts are kept in place by means of press fitting. Thus, too much shrinkage and you will not be able to fit them into place. If the fit is not tight enough, they will not be kept in place. This is not least important for the bearing. I have been experimenting with assumptions of linear correspondence between model dimensions and actual dimensions in the 3D printed objects, but without much success. Trial and error is most likely your best friend in this context.

Update:
I have been given a chance to 3-D printed this duck call myself at my school and after looking over the design of the duck call I have seen that the reed is way to small for the duck call. So I have changed this and increased the size to .012 inches. Also I have had to increase the gap in the insert to .255 inches. I will leave the first file for the insert just in case for some reason someone wanted it and will be putting the new reed file up. Original:
This is a duck call I modeled for the "make it loud" challenge. The program I used to make each part was Autodesk Inventor 2015. I decided to make a duck call because it seems as if the mechanics behind how they work is very simple. There is a thin plastic chip inside that moves up and down really fast with the force of a person's breath. I have attempted to make a model that will work as a real duck call once 3-D printed and fully constructed. I don't have a 3-D printer so I haven't been able to try and see if this model actually works. I hope there are people out there willing to print it out and test to see if it does work. And if anyone does try it please leave a comment of how the trial went.

title: Cable Chain optimized for larger CNC machine

description.text: We printed 10' of this cable chain for our 4'x4' Hedron Ooznest Openbuilds OxCNC machine. more info on our machine at http://hedron.technology/cncrouter. We printed this chain at scale = 2.0. It easily snaps together though it is not as strong as the original by tosjduenfs. When we tried to snap together the original scaled 2X by tosjduenfs we could not snap them together easily so we modified the wall thickness for an easier fit. In my opinion, there is a balance that could be achieved between our two designs for the ultimate in fast printing, easy assembly and durability. All one would need to do is play around some more with the design files, which both tosjduenfs and I provide, this was good enough for us for now.

description.text:
I use this for calibrating parts that don't fit well together. I'd rather the outer be a little too small and the inner be a little be a little too big than the other way around.
My printer had been overstepping all x-y bounds of models by a tenth of a millimeter or so, but that adds up when parts are trying to fit together tightly. 
I found a setting in Slic3r under the advanced tab called "XY Size Compensation" and set the value to -0.16 so it shrinks the model dimensions to account for my printer's error. The cool thing is that it shrinks inner dimensions too so now outsides and insides of my parts are to spec.

title: Raspberry Pi 2 and Adafruit TFT display with angled base

description.text: This is a case for Raspberry Pi 2 with a Adafruit PiTFT display for the Raspberry Pi 1. It is Adafruit part #1601), which as Adafruit says on their website, works fine as long as you don't mind a bit of an overhang. The overhang makes it a bit of an odd case variant, but it works fine and actually doesn't look bad at all once it is in a case. The situation is that I wanted to use the Pi 2 due to the better performance, which is especially needed when running OctoPrint, a Pi camera, and OctoPiPanel displaying on the Adafruit TFT display. So I purchased a new Raspberry Pi 2, but I already had on hand the PiTFT display for the Pi 1 so I ended up designing this case rather than purchasing a new PiTFT display for the Pi 2. The case is a derivative/remix of the case Raspberry Pi 2 Safe and Secure with LCD screen or not thing #: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:784971, not only did I have to redesign the top for the display, but the middle piece interfered with the bottom of the display so I had to change it a bit too. And finally, I also added an angled base so that it has a nice reading angle when mounted on the base board for my Prusa i3 box frame. You can see that best in the second and third pictures.

remixed_from.title: Wargaming terrain: "czech hedgehog" - anti-tank obstacle defence

description.text:
I liked the design of don_eldarro's "Czech Hedgehog" in that it could be taken apart when not in use, but I wanted something that looked a bit more like the real thing. Getting something that looks exactly accurate with this three piece approach isn't really possible, but I think this gets a bit closer to the source object.
There are still a few adjustments I am thinking of making, but this is close enough to being finished that it should be safe to print.
I implemented this design in OpenSCAD, so take a look at the script if you want to make some tweaks. Of particular note is probably the variable used for tolerances; on my printer .5 mm is the sweet spot, but if you've got better hardware you could probably tighten that up a bit.

Notes: The STL file contains all the parts needed to assemble the final object. No support is necessary, though you may wan to turn on brim if your pieces start to curl up at the ends.

Assembly Place the two large arms back-to-back, with the L shaped holes aligned; then push the longer end of the tie rod through the middle. The stop in the tie rod is meant to help keep the object together and should be oriented so it points downwards.

description.text:
I like to keep an eye on my 3D printer while it's printing, but I needed a custom stand for my old webcam for my 3D printer.  
This stand has a base with a place for weights, or magnets. I added two magnets; one glued to the base of the 3D printer, and one glued inside the base of the webcam stand.  The hinge at the arm makes the stand very adjustable. it is held together with a 1/4"-20 bolt and nut. These are capped with a custom knob.  The webcam is also held in place with a capped-bolt.

title: Quarto asse Vers. 2.1 (Fourth axis) Laser 40 W chinese

description.text:
Per poter produrre dei disegni su oggetti cilindrici, in particolare bottiglie o vasellame in vetro ho avuto l'esigenza di creare il cosiddetto "quarto asse" per, far girar, appunto gli oggetti, invece che muovere l'asse y. Era necessario, oltre che adattarsi alla lunghezza dell'oggetto, poterlo posizionare alla distanza di messa a fuoco del laser.
Doveva anche adattarsi allo spazio interno del laser e per poter abbassare il quarto asse è stato necessario tagliarne il fondo.
Per la realizzazione servono:
barra filettata M8 1m
barra liscia 8mm 2m
8 cuscinetti lineari LM8U
6 cuscinetti a sfera M8 608ZZ
6 cuscinetti a rullini HK0810
viti, rondelle, bulloni M5, M8, M3 vari
Il mandrino Longworth lo trovate sul mio canale thingiverse. In order to produce designs on cylindrical objects, in particular bottles or tableware glass I had the need to create the so-called "fourth axis" for, to rotate, precisely the objects, rather than move the axis y. It was necessary, in addition to adapt to the length of the object, to position it at the distance of focus of the laser.
He also had to adapt to the inner space of the laser and to lower the fourth axis is necessary cut off the bottom.
threaded rod M8 1m
smooth bar 8mm 2m
8 linear bearings LM8U
6 ball bearings 608ZZ M8
6 needle bearings HK0810
screws, washers, bolts M5, M8, M3 various
The Longworth chuck can be found on my channel .

Just like my previous nema14, this is nema17 version, can be used on nema with longer than 25mm shaft. It use the motor shaft as extruder shaft to. And since its rotate at different speed, please give it a high quality grease to prevent wear on both shaft and MK8 gear.
Please check print setting notes.
Bearing use 625
For clipping the idler to the body, use metal PEG like on the photo, or you can use other clip.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

50%

Notes: Support is for the Body2 only. For body1. rotate X 180
For idler, rotate 90 For gear, i use xy compensation -0.12 on my printer using Slic3r Print gear 3x

Make hole good Manually drill with 3mm bits for the Gear1
Manually drill 5mm bits for Orbit, do not drill the 3mm hole on orbit. Carefully put the MK8 into orbit and glue it. make sure it straight so perhaps, it will be better if you can use motor shaft to help then glue it a little using super glue. Take it out and put more glue. Clean the shaft and put the motorgear down to bottom of the shaft, and put super glue. Be carefull. Lubricate all gear using good grease Use small M3 to lock in place 3 gear to orbit. Print m4rr to help put M4 nuts to PTFE tube 4mm. or just use easyfit with 5mm thread.

title: FPV Board Camera 15 Degree Mount (Emax NightHawk 250)

description.text:
FPV Board Camera Mount for Emax NightHawk 250 Quad. Angled at 15 degrees. Camera is attached using four M2.4 x 6mm socket screws (Available at Home Depot). Screw holes spaced at 27mm.
Camera is recessed back so the lens does not protrude beyond the front pillars. If / when a crash happens, this will reduce the chance of any broken lenses. It also reduces the amount of debris the props fling onto the lens as well. (Wire management will be done in due time)
Prints in two pieces at 20% infill.

author: woody76

description.text: Update 10/27 - I have redone the angle of the clip and it sits much more comfortably while holding the controller more naturally. This is a mount for a Nexus 7 to connect with a PS4 controller and use the PS4 Remote Play App. It lets you stream your game to your hand while your family, friends, and others want to use the TV while you need to grind a few more Exp. The remote play app was ported to most android devices by here http://forum.xda-developers.com/android/apps-games/ps4-remote-play-android-thread-t3068225 This does not require root! However you will need a micro to micro usb cable, or we have a USB to micro adapter that works just as well. (The controller needs to be connected to the device) I printed without supports and the holes came out fine. But they would be neater with some support. The file is very easy to manipulate in Tinkercad. You can adjust the center of gravity, or shrink down the clip to fit another device. (I made the inside 3mm smaller than the device to make sure the hold was tight)
